column2: After the Treaty of Verdun in 843, the Carolingian Empire was a shadow of what it was under Charlemagne. With the deposition and death of Emperor Charles the Fat, however, the Empire has finally collapsed, and each part of it has elected a kinglet from their own bowels, the dream of a united Christian Europe seemingly dead... for now...

column2: After a long period of instability, the Iron Crown of the Lombards in Italy has been seized by Berengar II, who's legitimacy is under question. Meanwhile to the north, Otto of Saxony, king of Germany, waxes in power. As the new millennium slowly approaches, the post-Carolingian status-quo looks set to change forever, but who will come out on top?

column2: Having successfully conquered Italy, Otto the Great of Germany has been crowned Roman Emperor by the Pope, claiming the legacy of Charlemagne and the Roman emperors of old. But with the power and prestige come new challenges: the powerful lords of Germany and Italy, historically enjoying a large amount of autonomy, are unlikely to be happy with an increasingly powerful Emperor. Can the new Holy Roman Empire truly become a successor to the great Empires of time gone by?

column2: Emperor Henry II of the Holy Roman Empire has died childless, and with no obvious heir the Princes of the Empire have elected Conrad of Franconia of the Salian dynasty as the new King of the Germans. However, Conrad's support is hardly universal among his new vassals. Will he keep the Empire together, or are the Salians doomed to eventual obscurity?

column2: Rudolph III of Arles has died without children, bringing an end to the Burgundian branch of the Welf dynasty. As per an agreement made in 1006, however, the Kingdom of Arles has been inherited by the Holy Roman Emperor, becoming the third crown in the Imperial union.
column3: Rudolph III of Arles has died without children, bringing an end to the Burgundian branch of the Welf dynasty. As per an agreement made in 1006, however, the Kingdom of Arles has been inherited by the Holy Roman Emperor, becoming the third crown in the Imperial union.

column2: A storm is brewing in Europe. Long standing questions on the extent of the Papacy's secular power are being considered by reformists in Rome, led by Pope Gregory. Meanwhile, Henry IV of the Salian dynasty rules as Holy Roman Emperor, his predecessors having long used the clergy as a tool to counterbalance the feudal lords and treating the requirement of a Papal crowning as little more than a formality, rather than a sign of subservience to the Papacy. It seems like a clash between Emperor and Pope is inevitable, but who will come out on top?

column2: The Hussite movement stemmed from the teachings of Jan Hus, a Bohemian priest in the late 14th and early 15th centuries, who preached that the Catholic church had become corrupt and in need of reform. Based around concepts such as poverty of clergy, punishment of mortal sins and celebration of Communion of both kinds, bread and wine, the Hussites were precursors of the later Protestant movements of the Reformation.
